comment.author: 82096028@N00
comment._content: Commissariat is spelt incorrectly, it has two m's.

comment.author: 82096028@N00
comment._content: I recognise from other comments here that some of the spellings are using archaic forms and are taken from the original descriptions - but it raises an interesting debate about accessibility. If people want to find the material, here or in any archive, are they going to be able to do so if archaic or incorrect spellings were used and the modern equivalent is not also provided for search / reference purposes?

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content: Ah. This one is an error. That is Beato's spelling but my intention was that image titles and tags would use modern spelling to help with searching. Oh well. Easily fixed.

comment.author: 15751038@N02
comment._content: Obviously, Danny, because I'm commenting on your comments. Peace out, I'm over it.

comment.author: 82096028@N00
comment._content:
What riles me is your comment about "getting out much". When you have seen a bit more of the world and met some of its diverse inhabitants, then lecture to me about getting out much. 

I really don't care what or how any individual labels or tags their photographs - my own regularly see mispellings and mistagging. It does not really matter at all.

But when a publicly funded national institution cannot get their public presence correct, then it reflects badly on them, it reflects badly on this country and it sends bad messages to the rather large world that still looks towards Britain as a place of culture, literacy and education.

I spent considerable time over the past three months working in the United Arab Emirates and apart from doing my day job, the one thing that most people wanted me to share with them was the proper use of English, how to write in a lucid, clear way, how to pronouce words properly, how to bring their often fragmented English a little closer to what you and I are blessed with as native speakers (though some would dispute that in reference to you guys in the US!! - that's a joke btw).

It is therefore bloody annoying to see an organisation like the UK National Archives make silly errors.

As I said, it may not really matter to you (nor apparently to many other commentators either) but it actually does matter for the reasons I describe above.

So, carry on using whtevr wrds u wnt 2 use on yr Flckr pges, bt i xpect mi public orgs 2 do it prprly.

Rgrds 

D 

Lndn

comment.author: 15751038@N02
comment._content:
I was compelled to make my little quip after reading several of your corrections, and reading the UK National Archives repeated explanation that the spellings are using archaic forms and are taken from the original descriptions of the photographs... simple enough to understand.
My quip was just a sad attempt to amuse my tiny little small mind. Thank you for pointing out that my lack of travel all these years that I've been tending to family makes me way less than you. Oh wait! I did go somewhere once... if only I could recall.... Gotta go, laundry beckons.

comment.author: 15751038@N02
comment._content:
Oh, I'm the old woman smiling in the photo of "Cowtown Spicers". My sweet husband would never say anything much to a stranger. He's quiet that way. And I NEVER abbreviate, not even when texting with my hillbilly children. Jeez, you and I MUST lead terribly boring lives, to bicker so.
Carry on, grammar policeman.

comment.author: 15751038@N02
comment._content: Shit! Forgot the apostrophe before the "s" in archives to denote the possessive. What a rube I am!

comment._content: Oh Ronny! I just love you!
